title: Deuteronomy
enDesc: The Torah includes the first five of the twenty four books of the Tanakh. According to rabbinic tradition, the written laws together with the oral laws, which make up the halakhah were given through prophecy to Moses. Jewish tradition divides the book into parashiyot (sections). Each section corresponds to the weekly reading. The entire book is read over the course of one year. Christians divided the book into chapters and verses. This division has been used by Jews since the Middle Ages. Devarim (Deuteronomy) consists of three sermons by Moses delivered shortly before entering the Promised Land. The first sermon recalls the period of forty years of wondering in the wilderness and concludes with an exhortation to observe the Torah’s commandments. The second reminds the Israelites to remain loyal to God and not to follow strange gods. To observe the laws He has given them, on which possession of the Promised Land is dependent. The third provides comfort that even if Israel is unfaithful and exiled from the land, through repentance a return is possible.
